title: How many Mirais will Toyota sell or lease between January 2018 and June 2018, inclusive?
preds: Currently at 640 as of the end of May. Production has been lagging behind last year's numbers as of the last few months, so very little chance of reaching 900

640 cars between Jan and May (inclusive)
Max 213 cars  in one month this year, 296 last year.
this means less than 900 end of this month in my opinion. (ok 936 total if you add  640 and 296 . But June16 40 cars and in  June 17 129cars ) source for the numbers: http://carsalesbase.com/us-car-sales-data/toyota/toyota-mirai/

Numbers for May: http://carsalesbase.com/us-car-sales-data/toyota/toyota-mirai/ If we take the numbers at face value, Toyota'd have to sell 260 to reach 900. Not unprecedented but seems extremely unlikely given past numbers.

http://carsalesbase.com/us-car-sales-data/toyota/toyota-mirai/ hanging under 500
https://www.thecarconnection.com/overview/toyota_mirai_2017 Losing mkt share to other brands
538 through April. For the past two months, numbers have been lower than 2017. Guessing no more than 800 through June.
538 sold to date, even with the next 2 months likely to sell well only the lower two buckets are in play.
April volumes were 76, lower than March (83). A significant uplift was required to make the 900 - 1199 bracket which hasn't eventuated.
Sales are dropping month on month, going to keep monitoring but right now I don't see the total getting over 900.

Got clarification: only US sales. 
Based on 4 month trend - not looking good.  http://carsalesbase.com/us-car-sales-data/toyota/toyota-mirai/ Will revise after May sales.

FYI - agree clarification on region required but question notes 3000 sales in USA and GJO/HFC have American perspective. So I’m answering based on USA only. Plus ranges would have aligned with uptick in USA sales.
538 after 4 months (2 months to go). Could they produce 181/month - yes. But does the market exist? Will they offer (further) incentives - don’t know. Lowering dramatically.
Toyota sold only 76 Mirais in April. https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/toyota-motor-north-america-reports-april-2018-sales-300640140.html

I calculated the average monthly sales (for the next 3 months) required to get to the required brackets, and worked out the frequency and % that these sales occurred from Sep '16: <900, 146/month, 12, 65%
900 - 1199, 146-279/month, 6, 32%
>1199, >346/month, 1, 5% There seems to be quite a bit of variation in sales, with a large spike in Aug '16 (371 in that month) and significant uplift from Sep '17. However, there has been a decline since Dec '17.  Looking back, the probability of the 3 month average being greater than 149 (required to get to 900 sales) given one month is below 100 (March was 83) is 22%.  I also looked at the Honda Clarity sales/leases which had a similar uplift starting Nov '17 but haven't had the same drop from Dec '17 onward. It's possible that the decline in Mirais sales isn't just a seasonal or industry variation but is specific to the car. I'm assigning low probability to the higher brackets, but of course there's always a chance of an Aug '16 like spike that changes things.

According to toyota website, Japanese sales for first quarter exceeded US sales, at 547.  Total world wide sales at 1035, for the quarter.  Based on the same sales ratios between Japan and US, expected sales for q2 is 1255.  However, the official tracker does not give you means to track japanese sales.  So should this figure only be us sales?
The official tracker does let you track european sales, however.  I've asked for clarification. https://newsroom.toyota.co.jp/en/corporate/20966057.html?adid=ag478_mail&padid=ag478_mail
462 in 3 months, puts Toyota on track of 924 in 6 months.

It's fair to expect some sort of ramp up given that car sales tend to go up in the spring and summer, which is also reflect in the historical data. Using last year's ramp but scaled up to account for the higher average sales so far this year, we will be in the ~1000k range. Even if we use last year's average of 153 we still end above 900. And if we use last year's Q2 numbers we end at 859. This seems unlikely. Buyer demand will be a constraining factor. I don't think the merits of hydrogen technology will matter all that much for this question. A more important consideration is that the general public is relatively unfamiliar with hydrogen relative to EVs or hybrids and this is not going to change in three months. Also, this is subjective (and I place almost zero weight on it) but the Mirai is a strange looking car. Poor aesthetics mean that it will take more to convince somebody to buy something unfamiliar. More importantly, the lack of fueling stations is a problem and means that the market is largely contained to California. On the optimistic side of the 13/day production statistic is to be trusted (http://www.wired.co.uk/article/toyota-mirai-hydrogen-car-replicate-prius-success) then this could mean they could ramp up production (and perhaps use extra inventories from the past) to meet higher demand.
https://newsroom.toyota.co.jp/en/corporate/20966057.html?adid=ag478_mail&padid=ag478_mail Apparently they have not increased production. And a smaller new model for 2019
According to Toyota here:  the forecast is 2600 cars this year. https://newsroom.toyota.co.jp/en/corporate/20966057.html?adid=ag478_mail&padid=ag478_mail

Jan-March period in... 2016:  97
2017: 311
2018: 462 The bump came from sales in January though.
I am thinking rest of year will resemble last year.
If so, it might come in under 900. Range 860 (if continues at last year's pace) to 1100 (if 1.5x last year continues from 1st quarter).

We are just over 450 halfway through the time frame. Based on that I think the final number ends up around 900, although sales in the Apr-Jun time frame have been higher than in the Jan-Mar time frame in the last two years.

Difficult to tell what may have caused the sales trend in the first three months of this year to reverse direction as compared to 2016 & 2017.  Not sure if sales trend will slowly begin to reverse in the second quarter. 
In light of the first quarter results, I can't foresee sales averaging 246 or more per month in the 2nd quarter, therefore all sales projections above 1199 have 0 probability!  Under the circumstances, I suspect sales will continue to be slow in the next quarter or so.  Will Toyota be able to sell more than 146 per month over the second quarter, difficult to be sure but I believe April sales will go a long way in answering this question.
March was a miserable month for Mirai, where does the push come from for April and May?

0-55-45-0-0 now 1-84-15-0-0 Was too optimistic. Will have to check the consumer and business sentiments and confidence but gut is telling me people are wary of the Trumpy tarriff chaos.  Will drop brackets again if undersells the trendline in April. To maybe 20-79-1-0-0

Not sure why the bad March. Supply? Weather? Or per my prior comment maybe most of the early adopting demand has been met? You know it’s not because Tesla Model 3’s are so widely available. Didn’t foresee such a bad March - thought it would be semi consistent. Another bad month could potentially be a trend...
Making this a little more conservative.
Oooooouch.   83 sold in March for a total of 462 YTD.

US sales for 2016: 1034; and 2017: 1838. Assuming a linear growth there would be 402 sold mid 2018 bringing the sales by the end of June to 2240. But this might be a tad optimistic given Trump's protectionist tendencies and the pissing match he's having with China. So maybe halving that growth would be more realistic bringing total sales by the end of June to 2039.

Based on the sales figures linked and assuming they represent sales and loans (as it is stated that "Since 2015, Toyota has sold or leased over 3,000 Mirais in the US"), I assume a growth rate of 128%.
This figure is based on the growth rate YoY of the last 5 months and gives 1553 cars sold or loaned in 2018.
Taking a longer time window (8 months) the figure would be 1398, that is still within the 1200 - 1499 range.
"Cleaning" the stats from particular effects (like the 371 cars sold in August 2016) would let me increase the forecast. On the other hand I would take into consideration other aspects, 
- the possible slower growth rate (risk) due to unsufficient Hydrogen filling stations
- the increasing hype for electric and specific the long range possibility thanks to hydrogen

Home loans are public data, so my question is: are motor vehicle loans public also? Then again they're leasing them, not borrowing to own them. Usually.  Without seeing any data it's all just gut instincts and relying on indicators like overall car sales, similar models, gauging interest from a zeitgist (search terms?) and reviews as well as the sentiment/performance of the car, economic indicators (at least in state of California).  My original forecast was based on extrapolating previous years figures and putting in a ceiling based on overall car sales declining in the US. Now it seems the hydrogen refill stations aren't there. Chicken and egg. Why buy the car unless you live within 10 miles of a station, or it's close by your commute or where you travel to around LA or SF.
Making a small adjustment today and will likely make a dramatic one after march numbers are released.

There have already been 379 sold in January and February. If they only meet the same time period as last year for this year that brings it up to 894, making under 900 very unlikely since the sales are growing. If they are a bit higher based on January than last year at 240 for each of the four remaining months we get to 1339 which seems unlikely. At 160 per month for the next four we hit 1019 which seems like a good base case outcome. Particularly the first half of the year seems to be about half the sales rate as the second half of the year, so I think this is a good estimate.

0-1-85-14-0 now 0-55-40-5-0. Hydrogen refill points just aren't there. Demand isn't going to take off if stations aren't there to supply the H2 gas.  Seems they'll get to around 2500 to 3200 for 2018, where December is the top selling month, and weighting first half of the year at 30 to 35%, so around the 800 to 900 mark for this question.

Only tangentially related to this question but some interesting background on hydrogen cars. Articles argues they will be part of the future. Neither endorsing nor denying the claim...
https://postmediadriving.wordpress.com/auto-news/news/the-future-still-belongs-to-hydrogen-cars-not-electrics-say-auto-execs

Per @bobrown (do you know bob loblaw? Bad Joke); like nuclear fusion hydrogen has been called “the fuel of the future and it always will be”. Toyota has only ramped up production so much. Limited infrastructure. Something North of 1 000 sounds about right. Per article, they can build 13/day; 4 605/year and 2 687 for export (mostly USA). So we’re in the 1 200 range (taking a few out of California).
http://www.wired.co.uk/article/toyota-mirai-hydrogen-car-replicate-prius-success
This is production limited. not likely to surprise much. current trends suggest around 1200.

Assume 2018 sales are similar to 2017 sales - most everyone who wanted one has one.
Lease at $350/month is reasonable, with free fuel it is even a better deal, but locale is limited.
Growth of fuel stations does NOT support a hockey stick year for hydrogen.
It's the only reason to buy this vehicle, no style or other features to sway my choice.

When will the data update? A bit of a silly question for us to forecast on if we can't see the monthly sales data. Need to find another source. I'm surprised there isn't a central govt database besides VIN. Since VINs are random selections given to each chassis/engine as they're made based on the manufacturers make and model we can't really use that.

Toyota, despite Tesla and others push towards EV has chosen a different - and superior technology. 
While better does not always win (Beta, anyone?), it is a persuasive element.  Some facts:  1.   Greater range than most EVs at 312 miles. 
2.  No reduction in range in cold Weather. 
3.  Fillup time measured in 3-5 minutes, not 3-5 hours. 
4.  Contrary to car enthusiasts, who claim that battery technology has room to grow and fuel cells do not - 
Fuel cells have room to shrink.  Current projections will decrease the size of the fuel cell by 50% in the next generation decreasing the cost of the vehicle and increasing the range.  Toyota is rolling out hydrogen refueling stations as promised.  30 in CA, to which 19 will be added this year and a further 12 between Boston  and NYC. Toyota has a history of meticulous engineering and smooth rollouts.   Straightline linear projects of last years sales is over 1500.   I believe they will add more incremental.  Links:
http://www.greencarcongress.com/2018/01/20180123-mirai.html
http://www.greencarcongress.com/2018/01/20180118-mirai.html
http://www.greencarcongress.com/2018/01/20180119-toyota.html
http://www.philly.com/philly/business/cars/car-reviews/an-hour-alone-in-the-hydrogen-powered-toyota-mirai-20170922.html
Incentives still in place by Toyota will ramp sales.  Running about 50% ahead of LY sales.

I'm really curious as to what the impact on base material costs will be for Toyota after implementation of the Aluminum tariff...I don't even know if they manufacture those here or not. If they do there are several state of the art steel mills coming up to speed in the south - like BRS (big river steel) On the Mississippi in Osceola AR. The tariff is a huge shot in the arm right now, but as the supply of scrap steel drys up what happens. Thinking out loud.

If oil (and petrol or 'gas' as they say in Yankee Land) goes higher I'll shift my answers higher. Also would depend on the marketing spend or word of mouth. If the car becomes better known then sales should go higher right? Sold 1800+ last year, but with competition and car sales trending down (perhaps the economy too and savings as well as income with this WH admin making uncertain crazy decisions on a whim). So lets say they sell 2400 in 2018, that could be around 1100 to 1400 or so for first half. 379 already in Jan and Feb. So if they avg around 200 a month then the middle bracket seems most likely.
Correcting bad math on my part. 379in two months. Probably +1000

This is a commuter car for city dwellers. Down 'n' back to work, and the food store or to get wifeie a bottle of wine go watch the football game at the local sports bar and eat some wings. Oh ya great gas saver and at a 340 U.S. $ lease with a 15,000 $ gas credit WOW not bad that will buy a lot of wings and cold beer for the game. 
cool...
Brian

The market for H2 fuel cell vehicles is limited by the available of H2 fueling stations. Thus, for now, I do not expect overall demand for fuel cell cars to jump drastically. Toyota has sold 379 units in during Jan & Feb of 2018. To exceed the various thresholds, Toyota will have to average the following monthly sales for the next 4 months:
900 --> average 104/mo
1200 --> average 164/mo
1500 --> average 224/mo
1800 --> average 355/mo
Toyota has sold an average of 226 Mirai's over the past 6 months. If this continues, Toyota will be on track to sell over 1500 cars in by June 30. However, the Mirai sales curve has been declining by an average of 67 cars/mo. from its peak in December. This suggests that the sustainable rate will be less than the baseline predicted rate of 226 cars/mo.  How much lower depends on 3 major factors: (1) fuel cell car sales growth depends on easy access to refueling stations. With no major increases in refueling stations predicted over the next 4 months, car sales will remain constrained. (2) Vehicle cost and design remain a serious limitations. Compared to the Camry, the Mirai costs $25k more. Styling of the Mirai is also undesirable. (3) The Mirai faces serious competition from the Honda Clarity Hybrid. The Mirai lacks EV ability. No driver wants to be stranded with an empty tank. As a result, Clarity sales figures have skyrocketed compared to the Mirai, with 3512 sold in the past 3 months vs. 675.  I believe Honda will continue to cannibalize FC vehicle sales from Toyota until Toyota responds such as improving styling, dropping the cost, or offering a hybrid version.  With these 3 factors, I predict that Mirai sales will remain flat at 166/mo through June, putting it on track to sell slightly more than 1200 cars by mid-year. I have a difficult time seeing sales plummet to less than 104/mo. over the next 4 months. https://www.thecarconnection.com/car-compare-results/honda_fcx-clarity_2018-vs-toyota_mirai_2018
Last year total was 2017 	1.838. Half of that is around 919 as a lower bound, but the sales have been consistently higher this year. 1137 based on current sales to date.

Do Californians like these things? January: 213
February: 166 51% increase over same months last year. That would imply 1069 by mid-year.  Not sure why the question asks "sell or lease", but the page it links to is sales only. Will have to update in about a week, as consensus is not yet established.
Sales will increase with growth in hydrogen stations AND the public's understanding of the systems. So far, only the informed early adopters are on board.

Going low (80% under 900) given relative scarcity of infrastructure as opposed to ubiquitous electric. Electric cars generally look cooler (aside from a couple ugly ones) and that’s still a factor for many. Last - perhaps many of the early adopters already satisfied with the ~3000 cars already there. Expect around 900 in 6 months - maybe slightly more.

According to research electric cars have a 73% efficiency rating compared to only a 22% efficiency rating for hydrogen fuel cell propulsion cars (https://www.greencarreports.com/news/1113175_electric-cars-win-on-energy-efficiency-vs-hydrogen-gasoline-diesel-analysis). Californians are known for their 'green' ethos, and a statistic such as this will not go undetected, which is likely why only 3,000 Mirais have been sold in the State, since 2015.

Based on the average sales over the last several months, and noticing sales in January have usually been lower than later on in the year. I think sales will be a little higher in the next five months than in January so I think we up somewhere around 1,400 cars.
Looks like the average the past few months has been 200-250.
